answers.answer: You asked about the same exposure last May and were reassured by Dr. Hook, in unmistakably clear terms, that you were not at risk for HIV.  No medical conditions and no medicine delay HIV seroconversion; diabetes certainly does not do so.  (Advanced immune deficiency of the sort that occurs in terminal cancer might delay seroconversion, but even that is theoretical, without known actual cases.)Your test results prove you weren't infected.  Your fears are not rational and "frightened beyond believe" is a gross overreaction that suggests an emotional instability that might benefit from professional attention.  I suggest it out of compassion, not criticism.HHH, MD

question: Dear Dr's. Thank you for all of your help and great information. I have what I think may be a unique area of concern. I had a potential exposure by both inserting a cut finger into the vagina of a woman whose HIV status is unknown to me, and performing mutual masturbation where my penis was very close to her vagina and may have likely touched her vagina. I don't think my penis went in but I was pretty drunk and don't exactly remember everything with clarity.This happened in late March and I was tested at 6 wks and 15.5 weeks after the exposure by ELISA and both were negative. Today, I found out that I have early onset diabetes which I'll bet has been coming on for a while. I have read on another website that diabetes can cause a delay in seroconversion and now I am horrified that my prior tests are not reliable as seroconversion may have been delayed by diabetes. My doctor agreed to do another ELISA test today and is also ordering a P24 test in the event seroconversion has not occurred. Today would be a week short of 6 months. I know this was likely a low risk exposure but I am now frightened beyond belief. Can you tell me what you know about the relationship between diabetes and HIV seroconversion and whether or not I have something to be concerned about? I do greatly appreciate your help and pray that you will answer my question. I will not hear back on both tests for another week to 10 days and I don't think I'll make it without some direction on whether or not my fears are rational. Please respond asap. Thanks so much.
title: diabetes and seroconversion
